FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

1. Accidental Release Prevention Policies

Humboldt-St. Vincent Elevator has developed a risk management program and an emergency response plan to address the requirements of 40 CFR 68 revised 2004 regulations of the Clean Air Act in June 1999. Humboldt-St. Vincent Elevator is extremely diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community. Humboldt-St. Vincent Elevator staff is highly trained and utilize modern equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely storing and distributing anhydrous ammonia.

Humboldt-St. Vincent Elevator has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Anhydrous Ammonia Storage System. Humboldt-St. Vincent Elevator?s policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 

2. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Humboldt-St. Vincent Elevator is located at 1500 Highway 75, Humboldt, Minnesota in the county of Kittson. The primary activity at the Facility is the storage, and sale of fertilizers, in addition to, the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to farmers.

Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient. Anhydrous ammonia is received and stored in 30,000-gallon and 25,000 gallon storage tanks (bullets) at the site. The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia handled in this process is 420,000 pounds.

3. Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Analysis

Per 40 CFR 68 Regulations, the description covering the worst-case and alternative case release scenarios has been eliminated from the executive summary. 

-Risk Considerations

Although the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia has inherent po

tential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; Humboldt-St. Vincent Elevator has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event (e.g., In the event of a release, sudden rupture and flashing of ammonia would be highly turbulent. Turbulence causes entrainment of air and the released vapor dilutes much more quickly than is shown in the model).

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an ammonia release:

   -Automatic/Manual Shutdown
   -Well designed Relief System.
   -The history of the Humboldt-St. Vincent Elevator (i.e., no CalARP-applicable anhydrous or aqueous ammonia releases) reflects the adequacy of the design and diligence of the plant staff in safely storing and distributing anhydrous and aqueous ammonia. 

4. Accidental Release Prevention Program 

As part of the implementation of this Risk Management Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Humboldt-St. Vincent Elevator to manage process safety issues associated with the use of anhydrous ammonia. In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.

The facility?s maximum intended inventory of anhydrous ammonia is 420,000 lbs.  Therefore, the covered process has over the 10,000 lbs threshold quantity for EPA RMP and OSHA PSM. As a result, the anhydrous ammonia covered process is subject to EPA RMP

Program Level 3 and OSHA PSM. 

The Anhydrous Ammonia Prevention Program 3 elements include:

   -Process Safety Information
   -Process Hazard Analysis
   -Operating Procedures
   -Training
   -Mechanical Integrity
   -Management of Change
   -Pre-Startup Safety Review
   -Compliance Audits
   -Incident Investigation
   -Employee Participation
   -Hot Work Permit
   -Contractors

In addition, key emergency response elements were addressed in the Business Emergency Plan. See EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM below.

5. Five-Year Accident History

There have been no EPA-applicable releases of ammonia at Humboldt-St. Vincent Elevator in the past five years.

6. Emergency Response Program

Humboldt-St. Vincent Elevator is not a First Responder.  Employees are trained to evacuate and call 911 in case of an emergency.  Humboldt-St. Vincent Elevator will coordinate with local Fire Department and First Responders. Humboldt-St. Vincent Elevator has filed a Business Emergency Plan to help coordinate with local responders.


8. Planned Changes To Improve Safety

Humboldt-St. Vincent Elevator is continually looking to improve the safety of its employees and the community by implementing any reasonable safeguards to reduce the risk of a potentially hazardous release. The facility currently meets and exceeds all requirement of 40 CFR 68 under the Clean Air Act and will continue to comply with any and all federal, state and county regulations. 

9. Flammables: Worst Case

The use of flammable materials at Humboldt-St. Vincent Elevatoris not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable. 

10. Flammables: Alternative Release

The use of flammable materials at Humboldt-St. Vincent Elevatoris not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.
